name: Chapter 10: Availability Zones
description: Flashcards to explain the role and benefit of using multiple Availability Zones in AWS for resilience and performance.

cards.front: Your app is running entirely in a single Availability Zone. What risk are you exposing it to?
cards.back: If that Availability Zone experiences a failure (like power loss or natural disaster), your entire application could go down, since there’s no redundancy.
cards.example: A pizza shop with one oven has to shut down if that oven breaks. With only one AZ, there’s no backup.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: One or more isolated data centers within an AWS Region that provide high availability and fault isolation.
A virtual server running in the AWS cloud to host applications.

cards.front: How can you ensure your AWS application keeps running even if one Availability Zone fails?
cards.back: Deploy Amazon EC2 instances across multiple Availability Zones within the same Region to achieve high availability and fault tolerance.
cards.example: Two pizza shops in different locations ensure service continues if one has an emergency. Similarly, using multiple AZs keeps your app online.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: Ensures systems remain operational with minimal downtime during failures.
Deploying resources across multiple Availability Zones for increased fault tolerance.

cards.front: Why are Availability Zones designed to be both separated and closely connected?
cards.back: AZs are far enough apart to protect against local disasters, but close enough to provide low-latency network communication between them.
cards.example: Two pizza shops far enough to avoid the same outage, yet close enough to share staff and ingredients. AWS AZs follow the same design logic.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: Minimal delay in data communication between systems.
Architectural design that prevents localized failures from impacting other components.

cards.front: What is the benefit of using multiple Availability Zones for your application?
cards.back: It increases resilience by allowing your application to continue running even if one AZ fails, thus minimizing downtime and data loss.
cards.example: If one pizza shop closes due to a power outage, the other can still serve customers. Similarly, multiple AZs keep your app available.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: The ability of a system to recover quickly from failures.
The capability of a system to continue operating properly in the event of a failure.
